keyTakeAways: Sir David Attenborough, at 99 years old, became the oldest winner of a Daytime Emmy for his work on 'Secret Lives of Orangutans'.

The documentary 'Secret Lives of Orangutans' won three awards at the 52nd Annual Daytime Emmys, including outstanding daytime personality, non-daily, outstanding music direction and composition, and outstanding directing team.
Sir David previously held the record for oldest Daytime Emmy winner with Dick Van Dyke at 98 years old, now surpassed.
Sir David's long-standing career in natural history broadcasting, spanning over 70 years, has made him a globally recognized figure in science communication and environmental advocacy.
The film 'Ocean', released earlier in the year, is described by Sir David as one of his most significant projects, with a focus on biodiversity and climate change mitigation.
The award recognition underscores the global impact of natural history programming and the role of influential figures like Attenborough in shaping public awareness of environmental issues.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sir David Attenborough, at 99 years old, has become the oldest recipient of a Daytime Emmy Award for his documentary 'Secret Lives of Orangutans', winning in the outstanding daytime personality, non-daily category and two additional awards. The documentary, which follows orangutans in Sumatra, Indonesia, also won for music direction and directing. This achievement surpasses the previous record held by actor Dick Van Dyke, who won at 98. Sir David's long-standing career in natural history broadcasting, including iconic works like 'Life on Earth' and 'The Blue Planet', has cemented his global influence. The recognition underscores the growing importance of environmental storytelling in media and highlights the role of influential figures like Attenborough in advancing public awareness of climate and biodiversity issues.
